awd_titl_txt: Longitudinal Study of a Relocated Community in Zambia
awd_abstract_narration: This pilot project will support a fieldworker to spend six months in            Zambia to update a census begun by an anthropologist (Dr. Colson) in            1957.  The people studied are the Valley Tonga, who were relocated in           order to make way for the construction of a gigantic dam in the 1950's.         Since that time Professor Colson and her colleagues have made periodic          visits to this community to assess the direction of change in the social        organization of the affected peoples.  This project will allow the              census to be updated to include second and third generation families.           The focus of the research is to assess the changes in traditional               knowledge and practice which facilitate the Tonga people's adaptation to        changing modern situations.                                                                                                                                     This research is important because large scale population resettlements         are going on all the time in the modern world of major development              projects.  This long-term study of one resettled people sheds light on          the conditions and adaptations of resettled peoples everywhere these            changes are going on.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences
